Yes, y=
ou are write. There are also one-time setUp and tearDown methods
that was i=
n TestSetup object in JUnit 3.8. See code examples above.

 
 
> - For 120 =
different test case, if it has same format and  is in text
> file, I recomm=
end writing another class to process reading it and
> return turn each pair=
. 
> 
> Let test case use this class to load those test cases, this will sa=
ve
> amount of time instead of doing them all by hand.
You can do it using =
@Parametrized method. You can write separate class
and use in @Parametrized=
 method or you can write an actual code their.  

> - Another issue, I thin=
k  it's better to divide those 120  cases into
> different catagories (ie. =
simple selection, selection with where
> clause etc...) . Write a test case=
 for each catagory.  So that when
> your code break you can analyse which k=
ind of sql query is the reason.
> 
> I'm quite new to JUnit too, so if some=
 expert see any mistakes or any
> recommends.  
> 
> Hope it helps
>
This i=
s very deep point. When you write your tests with parametrized
method, that=
 is when your test your class with different inputs, you
should divide your=
 input in to EQUIVALENCE CLASSES. 
Let me explain this in more simple examp=
le. Suppose, you want to check
Math.sqrt(double a) methods. What values sho=
uld you check? First of
all, you have to notice, that valid input is only [=
0, +Inf). So, all
values are spitted down at least to (-Inf, 0), [0, +Inf).=
 This are
your equivalence class in first approximation. You should try, sa=
y -7
from (-Inf, ), +20 from [0, +Inf). You should also try value that is
i=
n boundary of your interval, that is 0. Sometimes, it is reasonable
to test=
 also value that are "near" boundary, for example 1 and -1. It
can be the c=
ase, that this separation is not enough. First of all,
what about special d=
ouble values such as NaN? What about -Inf and
+Inf? And if you test them, p=
erhaps it is worth to test
Double.MAX_VALUE and Double.MIN_VALUE as "neares=
t" values? It can be
also reasonable to test the quadratic integer numbers =
separately.
(Quadratic number is number that is exact square, that is a is
=
Quadratic number iff exist number x such that x*x=3Da) (Run
System.out.prin=
tln(Math.pow(Math.sqrt(15), 2)); to see why this can be
important). So, you=
r equivalence class will be (-Inf, 0), {0},
(0,1,2,4,9, 16,... all quadrati=
c numbers}=3DQI, (0, +Inf)\quadratic
numbers QI, {NaN}, {-Inf}, {+Inf}.
In =
your case is up to your to decide how to divide to equivalence
classes. Par=
tition to simple selection, selection with where clause
etc can be or can b=
e not useful just as in the example with
Math.sqrt() and quadratic numbers.=
